doc_title: What I've Learned from Strength Training
body:
I started my journey with strength training primarily to improve my physical health, instill discipline in my routine, and experience measurable progress. I had always been drawn to activities that demanded both physical and mental commitment, and strength training presented a structured way to engage in self-improvement. The Push-Pull-Legs (PPL) program appealed to me due to its clear breakdown of muscle groups and the flexibility it offered in terms of scheduling.

My method of following the PPL split involves training three times a week, alternating between push days (focused on chest, shoulders, and triceps), pull days (targeting back and biceps), and leg days. A key principle I've adopted is progressive overload—gradually increasing the weight or volume of my workouts to stimulate muscle growth. I’ve found that consistency is paramount; rather than pushing for maximum intensity in every session, I prioritize maintaining a regular schedule. This structured approach allows me to build a solid foundation and mitigate the risk of burnout or injury.

Through my training, I have learned the importance of patience. Strength builds slowly, often in increments that can feel imperceptible week-to-week. This slow progress requires a mindset shift; I’ve come to appreciate that mastery is a marathon, not a sprint. Additionally, I’ve recognized the critical role of recovery—adequate rest is not a luxury but a necessity for growth. Focusing on technique over ego lifting has also been vital; I’ve observed that maintaining proper form not only enhances my performance but significantly reduces the likelihood of injury.

This experience mirrors my other pursuits, such as dance and machine learning model training. In dance, I practice deliberate movements, refining my technique incrementally to achieve a polished performance. Similarly, in machine learning, the process of tracking progress through metrics and evaluations parallels the way I monitor my improvement in strength training. Each lifting session becomes a data point in my personal growth, emphasizing the significance of iterative refinement.

However, challenges arise. Staying consistent amidst other commitments, managing fatigue from both physical exertion and daily life, and ensuring I avoid injury are ongoing hurdles. Balancing my strength training with my responsibilities in academic and extracurricular activities requires careful planning and prioritization. 

This journey connects deeply to my core identity as a competence-driven individual who values measurable improvement. I thrive on structured approaches in both my professional and personal life, and strength training has reinforced this inclination. The mental benefits are undeniable; I find that engaging in strength training serves as a form of stress management, providing clear goals and a sense of control over my physical and mental state.

Ultimately, the lessons I’ve garnered from strength training extend to various aspects of my life. Discipline and long-term thinking have become integral to how I approach challenges, whether they are technical in nature or related to my personal goals. Respecting the process, understanding that meaningful change takes time, and being deliberate in my practice has become a guiding principle, not only in the gym but in my academic and professional endeavors as well.
